<s> they buried john pendennis esquire formerly an eminent medical practitioner at bath and subsequently an able magistrate a benevolent landlord and a benefactor to many charities and public institutions in this neighbourhood and county with one of the most handsome funerals that had been seen since sir roger clavering was buried here the clerk said in the abbey church of clavering st <\s>
<s> a fair marble slab from which the above inscription is copied was erected over the fairoaks pew in the church <\s>
<s> on it you may see the pendennis coat of arms and crest an eagle looking towards the sun with the motto nec tenui penna to the present day <\s>
<s> doctor portman alluded to the deceased most handsomely and affectingly as our dear departed friend in his sermon next sunday and arthur pendennis reigned in his stead <\s>
<s> in which pendennis appears as a very young man indeed arthur was about sixteen years old we have said when he began to reign in person for i see that the artist who is to illustrate this book and who makes sad work of the likeness will never be able to take my friend off he had what his friends would call a dumpy but his mamma styled a neat little figure <\s>

<s> whereas helen pendennis put up the handsomest of memorials to her husband and constantly renewed it with the most precious oil <\s>
<s> as for arthur pendennis after that awful shock which the sight of his dead father must have produced on him and the pity and feeling which such an event no doubt occasioned i am not sure that in the very moment of the grief and as he embraced his mother and tenderly consoled her and promised to love her for ever there was not springing up in his breast a feeling of secret triumph and exultation <\s>

<s> when he with laura in his hand went into the kitchen on his way to the dog kennel the fowl houses and other his favourite haunts all the servants there assembled in great silence with their friends and the labouring men and their wives and sally potter who went with the post bag to clavering and the baker's man from clavering all there assembled and drinking beer on the melancholy occasion rose up on his entrance and bowed or curtseyed to him <\s>

<s> they buried john pendennis esquire formerly an eminent medical practitioner at bath and subsequently an able magistrate a benevolent landlord and a benefactor to many charities and public institutions in this neighbourhood and county with one of the most handsome funerals that had been seen since sir roger clavering was buried here the clerk said in the abbey church of clavering st <\s>
<s> a fair marble slab from which the above inscription is copied was erected over the fairoaks pew in the church <\s>
<s> on it you may see the pendennis coat of arms and crest an eagle looking towards the sun with the motto nec tenui penna to the present day <\s>
<s> doctor portman alluded to the deceased most handsomely and affectingly as our dear departed friend in his sermon next sunday and arthur pendennis reigned in his stead <\s>
<s> in which pendennis appears as a very young man indeed arthur was about sixteen years old we have said when he began to reign in person for i see that the artist who is to illustrate this book and who makes sad work of the likeness will never be able to take my friend off he had what his friends would call a dumpy but his mamma styled a neat little figure <\s>
<s> his hair was of a healthy brown colour which looks like gold in the sunshine his face was round rosy freckled and good humoured his whiskers when those facial ornaments for which he sighed so ardently were awarded to him by nature were decidedly of a reddish hue in fact without being a beauty he had such a frank good natured kind face and laughed so merrily at you out of his honest blue eyes that no wonder mrs <\s>
<s> pendennis thought him the pride of the whole county <\s>
<s> between the ages of sixteen and eighteen he rose from five feet six to five feet eight inches in height at which altitude he paused <\s>

<s> he was three inches taller than his father <\s>
<s> was it possible that any man could grow to be three inches taller than mr <\s>

<s> then pen's uncle offered to use his influence with his royal highness the commander in chief who was pleased to be very kind to him and proposed to get pen a commission in the foot guards <\s>

<s> pendennis thought him the pride of the whole county <\s>
<s> between the ages of sixteen and eighteen he rose from five feet six to five feet eight inches in height at which altitude he paused <\s>
<s> but his mother wondered at it <\s>
<s> he was three inches taller than his father <\s>
<s> was it possible that any man could grow to be three inches taller than mr <\s>

<s> the question of his return was debated and his uncle was for his going back <\s>

<s> then pen's uncle offered to use his influence with his royal highness the commander in chief who was pleased to be very kind to him and proposed to get pen a commission in the foot guards <\s>

<s> we will take the juvenal at afternoon school he said nodding to the captain and all the boys understanding the signal gathered up their books and poured out of the hall <\s>

<s> you would not have thought it was the same man <\s>

<s> it is a pity to take the boy away unless there is <\s>

<s> my wife will be very happy to see you <\s>

<s> there's no other son is there <\s>

<s> whereupon this colloquy came to an end <\s>
<s> and arthur pendennis got into the postchaise with his uncle never to come back to school any more <\s>
<s> as the chaise drove through clavering the hostler standing whistling under the archway of the clavering arms winked the postilion ominously as much as to say all was over <\s>
<s> the gardener's wife came and opened the lodge gates and let the travellers through with a silent shake of the head <\s>
<s> all the blinds were down at fairoaks the face of the old footman was as blank when he let them in <\s>
<s> arthur's face was white too with terror more than with grief <\s>
<s> whatever of warmth and love the deceased man might have had and he adored his wife and loved and admired his son with all his heart he had shut them up within himself nor had the boy been ever able to penetrate that frigid outward barrier <\s>
<s> but arthur had been his father's pride and glory through life and his name the last which john pendennis had tried to articulate whilst he lay with his wife's hand clasping his own cold and clammy palm as the flickering spirit went out into the darkness of death and life and the world passed away from him <\s>
<s> the little girl whose face had peered for a moment under the blinds as the chaise came up opened the door from the stairs into the hall and taking arthur's hand silently as he stooped down to kiss her led him upstairs to his mother <\s>

<s> the room was darkened with the blinds down and surrounded by all the gloomy pictures of the pendennises <\s>

<s> the bottle had been opened for the squire four days before <\s>
<s> his hat was brushed and laid on the hall table his newspapers and his letter bag with john pendennis esquire fairoaks engraved upon the brass plate were there in waiting <\s>

<s> the former gave a detailed account of the seizure and demise of mr <\s>
<s> pendennis enlarged on his virtues and the estimation in which the neighbourhood held him on what a loss he would be to the magistrates bench the county hospital etc <\s>
<s> pendennis bore up wonderfully he said especially since master arthur's arrival <\s>

<s> the major would of course take entire superintendence of everything under this most impressive and melancholy occasion <\s>

<s> whereas helen pendennis put up the handsomest of memorials to her husband and constantly renewed it with the most precious oil <\s>
<s> as for arthur pendennis after that awful shock which the sight of his dead father must have produced on him and the pity and feeling which such an event no doubt occasioned i am not sure that in the very moment of the grief and as he embraced his mother and tenderly consoled her and promised to love her for ever there was not springing up in his breast a feeling of secret triumph and exultation <\s>

<s> but arthur had been his father's pride and glory through life and his name the last which john pendennis had tried to articulate whilst he lay with his wife's hand clasping his own cold and clammy palm as the flickering spirit went out into the darkness of death and life and the world passed away from him <\s>

<s> whereas helen pendennis put up the handsomest of memorials to her husband and constantly renewed it with the most precious oil <\s>
<s> as for arthur pendennis after that awful shock which the sight of his dead father must have produced on him and the pity and feeling which such an event no doubt occasioned i am not sure that in the very moment of the grief and as he embraced his mother and tenderly consoled her and promised to love her for ever there was not springing up in his breast a feeling of secret triumph and exultation <\s>

<s> and how quickly our wishes beget them <\s>
<s> when he with laura in his hand went into the kitchen on his way to the dog kennel the fowl houses and other his favourite haunts all the servants there assembled in great silence with their friends and the labouring men and their wives and sally potter who went with the post bag to clavering and the baker's man from clavering all there assembled and drinking beer on the melancholy occasion rose up on his entrance and bowed or curtseyed to him <\s>
<s> they never used to do so last holidays he felt at once and with indescribable pleasure <\s>

<s> they buried john pendennis esquire formerly an eminent medical practitioner at bath and subsequently an able magistrate a benevolent landlord and a benefactor to many charities and public institutions in this neighbourhood and county with one of the most handsome funerals that had been seen since sir roger clavering was buried here the clerk said in the abbey church of clavering st <\s>
<s> a fair marble slab from which the above inscription is copied was erected over the fairoaks pew in the church <\s>
<s> on it you may see the pendennis coat of arms and crest an eagle looking towards the sun with the motto nec tenui penna to the present day <\s>
<s> doctor portman alluded to the deceased most handsomely and affectingly as our dear departed friend in his sermon next sunday and arthur pendennis reigned in his stead <\s>
<s> in which pendennis appears as a very young man indeed arthur was about sixteen years old we have said when he began to reign in person for i see that the artist who is to illustrate this book and who makes sad work of the likeness will never be able to take my friend off he had what his friends would call a dumpy but his mamma styled a neat little figure <\s>
<s> his hair was of a healthy brown colour which looks like gold in the sunshine his face was round rosy freckled and good humoured his whiskers when those facial ornaments for which he sighed so ardently were awarded to him by nature were decidedly of a reddish hue in fact without being a beauty he had such a frank good natured kind face and laughed so merrily at you out of his honest blue eyes that no wonder mrs <\s>
<s> pendennis thought him the pride of the whole county <\s>

<s> they buried john pendennis esquire formerly an eminent medical practitioner at bath and subsequently an able magistrate a benevolent landlord and a benefactor to many charities and public institutions in this neighbourhood and county with one of the most handsome funerals that had been seen since sir roger clavering was buried here the clerk said in the abbey church of clavering st <\s>

<s> doctor portman alluded to the deceased most handsomely and affectingly as our dear departed friend in his sermon next sunday and arthur pendennis reigned in his stead <\s>
<s> in which pendennis appears as a very young man indeed arthur was about sixteen years old we have said when he began to reign in person for i see that the artist who is to illustrate this book and who makes sad work of the likeness will never be able to take my friend off he had what his friends would call a dumpy but his mamma styled a neat little figure <\s>

<s> but arthur had been his father's pride and glory through life and his name the last which john pendennis had tried to articulate whilst he lay with his wife's hand clasping his own cold and clammy palm as the flickering spirit went out into the darkness of death and life and the world passed away from him <\s>

<s> the former gave a detailed account of the seizure and demise of mr <\s>
<s> pendennis enlarged on his virtues and the estimation in which the neighbourhood held him on what a loss he would be to the magistrates bench the county hospital etc <\s>

<s> so it was with this in a word that mrs <\s>

<s> let a man pray that none of his womankind should form a just estimation of him <\s>
<s> if your wife knew you as you are neighbour she would not grieve much about being your widow and would let your grave lamp go out very soon or perhaps not even take the trouble to light it <\s>
<s> whereas helen pendennis put up the handsomest of memorials to her husband and constantly renewed it with the most precious oil <\s>
<s> as for arthur pendennis after that awful shock which the sight of his dead father must have produced on him and the pity and feeling which such an event no doubt occasioned i am not sure that in the very moment of the grief and as he embraced his mother and tenderly consoled her and promised to love her for ever there was not springing up in his breast a feeling of secret triumph and exultation <\s>

<s> he had determined that that part of his life should not be renewed <\s>
<s> in the midst of the general grief and the corpse still lying above he had leisure to conclude that he would have it all holidays for the future that he wouldn't get up till he liked or stand the bullying of the doctor any more and had made a hundred of such day dreams and resolves for the future <\s>
<s> how one's thoughts will travel <\s>
<s> and how quickly our wishes beget them <\s>
<s> when he with laura in his hand went into the kitchen on his way to the dog kennel the fowl houses and other his favourite haunts all the servants there assembled in great silence with their friends and the labouring men and their wives and sally potter who went with the post bag to clavering and the baker's man from clavering all there assembled and drinking beer on the melancholy occasion rose up on his entrance and bowed or curtseyed to him <\s>
<s> they never used to do so last holidays he felt at once and with indescribable pleasure <\s>

<s> they buried john pendennis esquire formerly an eminent medical practitioner at bath and subsequently an able magistrate a benevolent landlord and a benefactor to many charities and public institutions in this neighbourhood and county with one of the most handsome funerals that had been seen since sir roger clavering was buried here the clerk said in the abbey church of clavering st <\s>
<s> a fair marble slab from which the above inscription is copied was erected over the fairoaks pew in the church <\s>
<s> on it you may see the pendennis coat of arms and crest an eagle looking towards the sun with the motto nec tenui penna to the present day <\s>
<s> doctor portman alluded to the deceased most handsomely and affectingly as our dear departed friend in his sermon next sunday and arthur pendennis reigned in his stead <\s>
<s> in which pendennis appears as a very young man indeed arthur was about sixteen years old we have said when he began to reign in person for i see that the artist who is to illustrate this book and who makes sad work of the likeness will never be able to take my friend off he had what his friends would call a dumpy but his mamma styled a neat little figure <\s>

<s> whereas helen pendennis put up the handsomest of memorials to her husband and constantly renewed it with the most precious oil <\s>
<s> as for arthur pendennis after that awful shock which the sight of his dead father must have produced on him and the pity and feeling which such an event no doubt occasioned i am not sure that in the very moment of the grief and as he embraced his mother and tenderly consoled her and promised to love her for ever there was not springing up in his breast a feeling of secret triumph and exultation <\s>

<s> when he with laura in his hand went into the kitchen on his way to the dog kennel the fowl houses and other his favourite haunts all the servants there assembled in great silence with their friends and the labouring men and their wives and sally potter who went with the post bag to clavering and the baker's man from clavering all there assembled and drinking beer on the melancholy occasion rose up on his entrance and bowed or curtseyed to him <\s>

<s> they buried john pendennis esquire formerly an eminent medical practitioner at bath and subsequently an able magistrate a benevolent landlord and a benefactor to many charities and public institutions in this neighbourhood and county with one of the most handsome funerals that had been seen since sir roger clavering was buried here the clerk said in the abbey church of clavering st <\s>
<s> a fair marble slab from which the above inscription is copied was erected over the fairoaks pew in the church <\s>
<s> on it you may see the pendennis coat of arms and crest an eagle looking towards the sun with the motto nec tenui penna to the present day <\s>
<s> doctor portman alluded to the deceased most handsomely and affectingly as our dear departed friend in his sermon next sunday and arthur pendennis reigned in his stead <\s>
<s> in which pendennis appears as a very young man indeed arthur was about sixteen years old we have said when he began to reign in person for i see that the artist who is to illustrate this book and who makes sad work of the likeness will never be able to take my friend off he had what his friends would call a dumpy but his mamma styled a neat little figure <\s>
<s> his hair was of a healthy brown colour which looks like gold in the sunshine his face was round rosy freckled and good humoured his whiskers when those facial ornaments for which he sighed so ardently were awarded to him by nature were decidedly of a reddish hue in fact without being a beauty he had such a frank good natured kind face and laughed so merrily at you out of his honest blue eyes that no wonder mrs <\s>
<s> pendennis thought him the pride of the whole county <\s>
<s> between the ages of sixteen and eighteen he rose from five feet six to five feet eight inches in height at which altitude he paused <\s>

<s> he was three inches taller than his father <\s>
<s> was it possible that any man could grow to be three inches taller than mr <\s>

<s> then pen's uncle offered to use his influence with his royal highness the commander in chief who was pleased to be very kind to him and proposed to get pen a commission in the foot guards <\s>

<s> pendennis thought him the pride of the whole county <\s>
<s> between the ages of sixteen and eighteen he rose from five feet six to five feet eight inches in height at which altitude he paused <\s>
<s> but his mother wondered at it <\s>
<s> he was three inches taller than his father <\s>
<s> was it possible that any man could grow to be three inches taller than mr <\s>

<s> the question of his return was debated and his uncle was for his going back <\s>

<s> then pen's uncle offered to use his influence with his royal highness the commander in chief who was pleased to be very kind to him and proposed to get pen a commission in the foot guards <\s>

<s> we will take the juvenal at afternoon school he said nodding to the captain and all the boys understanding the signal gathered up their books and poured out of the hall <\s>

<s> you would not have thought it was the same man <\s>

<s> it is a pity to take the boy away unless there is <\s>

<s> my wife will be very happy to see you <\s>

<s> there's no other son is there <\s>

<s> whereupon this colloquy came to an end <\s>
<s> and arthur pendennis got into the postchaise with his uncle never to come back to school any more <\s>
<s> as the chaise drove through clavering the hostler standing whistling under the archway of the clavering arms winked the postilion ominously as much as to say all was over <\s>
<s> the gardener's wife came and opened the lodge gates and let the travellers through with a silent shake of the head <\s>
<s> all the blinds were down at fairoaks the face of the old footman was as blank when he let them in <\s>
<s> arthur's face was white too with terror more than with grief <\s>
<s> whatever of warmth and love the deceased man might have had and he adored his wife and loved and admired his son with all his heart he had shut them up within himself nor had the boy been ever able to penetrate that frigid outward barrier <\s>
<s> but arthur had been his father's pride and glory through life and his name the last which john pendennis had tried to articulate whilst he lay with his wife's hand clasping his own cold and clammy palm as the flickering spirit went out into the darkness of death and life and the world passed away from him <\s>
<s> the little girl whose face had peered for a moment under the blinds as the chaise came up opened the door from the stairs into the hall and taking arthur's hand silently as he stooped down to kiss her led him upstairs to his mother <\s>

<s> the room was darkened with the blinds down and surrounded by all the gloomy pictures of the pendennises <\s>

<s> the bottle had been opened for the squire four days before <\s>
<s> his hat was brushed and laid on the hall table his newspapers and his letter bag with john pendennis esquire fairoaks engraved upon the brass plate were there in waiting <\s>

<s> the former gave a detailed account of the seizure and demise of mr <\s>
<s> pendennis enlarged on his virtues and the estimation in which the neighbourhood held him on what a loss he would be to the magistrates bench the county hospital etc <\s>
<s> pendennis bore up wonderfully he said especially since master arthur's arrival <\s>

<s> the major would of course take entire superintendence of everything under this most impressive and melancholy occasion <\s>

<s> whereas helen pendennis put up the handsomest of memorials to her husband and constantly renewed it with the most precious oil <\s>
<s> as for arthur pendennis after that awful shock which the sight of his dead father must have produced on him and the pity and feeling which such an event no doubt occasioned i am not sure that in the very moment of the grief and as he embraced his mother and tenderly consoled her and promised to love her for ever there was not springing up in his breast a feeling of secret triumph and exultation <\s>

<s> but arthur had been his father's pride and glory through life and his name the last which john pendennis had tried to articulate whilst he lay with his wife's hand clasping his own cold and clammy palm as the flickering spirit went out into the darkness of death and life and the world passed away from him <\s>

<s> whereas helen pendennis put up the handsomest of memorials to her husband and constantly renewed it with the most precious oil <\s>
<s> as for arthur pendennis after that awful shock which the sight of his dead father must have produced on him and the pity and feeling which such an event no doubt occasioned i am not sure that in the very moment of the grief and as he embraced his mother and tenderly consoled her and promised to love her for ever there was not springing up in his breast a feeling of secret triumph and exultation <\s>

<s> and how quickly our wishes beget them <\s>
<s> when he with laura in his hand went into the kitchen on his way to the dog kennel the fowl houses and other his favourite haunts all the servants there assembled in great silence with their friends and the labouring men and their wives and sally potter who went with the post bag to clavering and the baker's man from clavering all there assembled and drinking beer on the melancholy occasion rose up on his entrance and bowed or curtseyed to him <\s>
<s> they never used to do so last holidays he felt at once and with indescribable pleasure <\s>

<s> they buried john pendennis esquire formerly an eminent medical practitioner at bath and subsequently an able magistrate a benevolent landlord and a benefactor to many charities and public institutions in this neighbourhood and county with one of the most handsome funerals that had been seen since sir roger clavering was buried here the clerk said in the abbey church of clavering st <\s>
<s> a fair marble slab from which the above inscription is copied was erected over the fairoaks pew in the church <\s>
<s> on it you may see the pendennis coat of arms and crest an eagle looking towards the sun with the motto nec tenui penna to the present day <\s>
<s> doctor portman alluded to the deceased most handsomely and affectingly as our dear departed friend in his sermon next sunday and arthur pendennis reigned in his stead <\s>
<s> in which pendennis appears as a very young man indeed arthur was about sixteen years old we have said when he began to reign in person for i see that the artist who is to illustrate this book and who makes sad work of the likeness will never be able to take my friend off he had what his friends would call a dumpy but his mamma styled a neat little figure <\s>
<s> his hair was of a healthy brown colour which looks like gold in the sunshine his face was round rosy freckled and good humoured his whiskers when those facial ornaments for which he sighed so ardently were awarded to him by nature were decidedly of a reddish hue in fact without being a beauty he had such a frank good natured kind face and laughed so merrily at you out of his honest blue eyes that no wonder mrs <\s>
<s> pendennis thought him the pride of the whole county <\s>

<s> they buried john pendennis esquire formerly an eminent medical practitioner at bath and subsequently an able magistrate a benevolent landlord and a benefactor to many charities and public institutions in this neighbourhood and county with one of the most handsome funerals that had been seen since sir roger clavering was buried here the clerk said in the abbey church of clavering st <\s>

<s> doctor portman alluded to the deceased most handsomely and affectingly as our dear departed friend in his sermon next sunday and arthur pendennis reigned in his stead <\s>
<s> in which pendennis appears as a very young man indeed arthur was about sixteen years old we have said when he began to reign in person for i see that the artist who is to illustrate this book and who makes sad work of the likeness will never be able to take my friend off he had what his friends would call a dumpy but his mamma styled a neat little figure <\s>

<s> but arthur had been his father's pride and glory through life and his name the last which john pendennis had tried to articulate whilst he lay with his wife's hand clasping his own cold and clammy palm as the flickering spirit went out into the darkness of death and life and the world passed away from him <\s>

<s> the former gave a detailed account of the seizure and demise of mr <\s>
<s> pendennis enlarged on his virtues and the estimation in which the neighbourhood held him on what a loss he would be to the magistrates bench the county hospital etc <\s>

<s> so it was with this in a word that mrs <\s>

<s> let a man pray that none of his womankind should form a just estimation of him <\s>
<s> if your wife knew you as you are neighbour she would not grieve much about being your widow and would let your grave lamp go out very soon or perhaps not even take the trouble to light it <\s>
<s> whereas helen pendennis put up the handsomest of memorials to her husband and constantly renewed it with the most precious oil <\s>
<s> as for arthur pendennis after that awful shock which the sight of his dead father must have produced on him and the pity and feeling which such an event no doubt occasioned i am not sure that in the very moment of the grief and as he embraced his mother and tenderly consoled her and promised to love her for ever there was not springing up in his breast a feeling of secret triumph and exultation <\s>

<s> he had determined that that part of his life should not be renewed <\s>
<s> in the midst of the general grief and the corpse still lying above he had leisure to conclude that he would have it all holidays for the future that he wouldn't get up till he liked or stand the bullying of the doctor any more and had made a hundred of such day dreams and resolves for the future <\s>
<s> how one's thoughts will travel <\s>
<s> and how quickly our wishes beget them <\s>
<s> when he with laura in his hand went into the kitchen on his way to the dog kennel the fowl houses and other his favourite haunts all the servants there assembled in great silence with their friends and the labouring men and their wives and sally potter who went with the post bag to clavering and the baker's man from clavering all there assembled and drinking beer on the melancholy occasion rose up on his entrance and bowed or curtseyed to him <\s>
<s> they never used to do so last holidays he felt at once and with indescribable pleasure <\s>

<s> they buried john pendennis esquire formerly an eminent medical practitioner at bath and subsequently an able magistrate a benevolent landlord and a benefactor to many charities and public institutions in this neighbourhood and county with one of the most handsome funerals that had been seen since sir roger clavering was buried here the clerk said in the abbey church of clavering st <\s>
<s> a fair marble slab from which the above inscription is copied was erected over the fairoaks pew in the church <\s>
<s> on it you may see the pendennis coat of arms and crest an eagle looking towards the sun with the motto nec tenui penna to the present day <\s>
<s> doctor portman alluded to the deceased most handsomely and affectingly as our dear departed friend in his sermon next sunday and arthur pendennis reigned in his stead <\s>
<s> in which pendennis appears as a very young man indeed arthur was about sixteen years old we have said when he began to reign in person for i see that the artist who is to illustrate this book and who makes sad work of the likeness will never be able to take my friend off he had what his friends would call a dumpy but his mamma styled a neat little figure <\s>
